headline: Tucker takes on liberal radio host over Kavanaugh allegations; opposition leader on the catastrophe unfolding in Venezuela
subHeadline: Guests: Ethan Bearman, Seth Barron, Penny Young Nance, Megan Fox, David Burstein, Victor Davis Hanson, Julio Borges

utterances.speaker: TUCKER CARLSON, HOST
utterances.sentences: Good evening and welcome to "Tucker Carlson Tonight." It's been more than a week since a California Psychology Professor named Christine Ford accused Judge Brett Kavanaugh of committing some form of sexual assault against her back in 1982. They were both high school students at the time. Ford's claim has stopped Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination in place. Washington has been consumed by the debate ever since. A number of Senate Republicans are said to be undecided on the question of Kavanaugh's guilt or innocence. utterances.sentences: He -- he hasn't been a judge for 36 years--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --the Supreme Court of the United States. You're talking -- hang - - hang on, hang on, you -- you are just-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --that hold the power in this country and we should be calling for -- for something else to change in our country right now.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --hang on. You're intentionally dodging my question--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --which is about the responsibility-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN

He's out there saving the country. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL AVENATTI, ATTORNEY

I believe that when these allegations are surfaced within the next 48 hours there will be no question that Brett Kavanaugh is not fit to sit on the U.S. Supreme Court. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well he hasn't provided the allegations needless to say. This guy's a buffoon. Ethan, these are serious charges presumably coming from serious people. The consequences are serious. Why let this charlatan intrude on the process? Why are Democrats allowing this guy to take center stage?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Well Michael Avenatti is taking a page out of Trump's own playbook, manipulating the media to his own benefit. But here's the difference. Michael Avenatti has actually brought the goods since he started representing Ms. Clifford Stormy Daniels. He's actually brought the goods when he's made these allegations. We've seen that with--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. But now he's saying that -- no, no, but hold on--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: --Michael Cohen.

utterances.sentences: --but in this specific case, he's suggesting he's got nothing to do with any of this, obviously. He's trying to stay famous. And he's saying that Brett Kavanaugh was part of a rape ring. He's not going to get sued for slander. He should. He's not. Did Democrats really want to be tied to someone that reckless, honestly?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: Well I -- I don't know anything about the allegation about a rape ring but he claims to have a -- a very well vetted out, a reliable another accuser and I'm very interested. He's teasing it out over 48 hours. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } So, that time hasn't quite come yet and I'm curious to see what he's going to bring because, again, he's brought the goods since he started representing Stormy Daniels. I mean I guess we'll see and maybe, you know, he's your -- he's your presidential candidate, so I guess we'll find out at least --

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, I'm -- I'm for Garcetti. I'm for Garcetti.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand has been maybe the most opportunistic of all in declaring Brett Kavanaugh guilty without any evidence to support it. It's hardly the first time that she has put her own ambition over what is true. A reporter who has followed her closely joins us next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well there are about a 100 U.S. senators, not about, there are literally a 100. About half of them have decided to keep Brett Kavanaugh off the Supreme Court no matter what. But there's only one, Kirsten Gillibrand. She stands alone in how flagrantly she's throwing out due process and individual rights for the sake of promoting herself and gaining politically.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KIRSTEN GILLIBRAND, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: I've heard from both sides, and I believe Dr. Blasey Ford and I believe Ms. Ramirez. You have women who are telling these stories about what happened to them and credibly accusing Judge Kavanaugh of violent behavior, of sexual assault, of -- of behavior that is disqualifying. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That was Harvey Weinstein's personal friend, Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York. Seth Barron has covered her and watched very closely as an Associate Editor of City Journal and he joins us tonight, Seth, when you see Senator Gillibrand position herself as a defender of all women everywhere, what's your response to that?

utterances.speaker: SETH BARRON, CITY JOURNAL
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, I don't know how it is that she's heard the two accusers and agrees with them because have they really said anything yet? I -- I don't know but--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Good question.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: --look, she has a long history -- Senator Gillibrand has a very long history of embracing whatever is expedient and dispensing with whatever is no longer expedient. She was elected in 2006--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: --as a conservative Democrat. Al D'Amato was basically her mentor and arranged for her to become the Senator after Hillary Clinton became Secretary of State in 2009. She was a conservative Democrat. She had an A rating from the NRA. You know, she had been a Philip Morris attorney. And then, when she became senator, she very quickly tacked Left. And, you know, one thing she said earlier this year that I thought was very revealing, asked why she net when she used to support, you know, deportation of illegal immigrants and now she was, you know, on board with the DREAMers, she said "Well, you know, I came from a district that was 98 percent White." And she said this is something she's embarrassed and ashamed about so, you know--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh -- oh I get it, so she's embarrassed and ashamed of her former constituents who launched her political career after she was a cigarette lawyer and I think she worked for Harvey Weinstein's law firm as well as,--

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: Yes, she did.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --of course, being his good friend there. So, when you see this former friend of Weinstein's and of Bill Clinton's who, of course, knew all about their reputations as abusers of women and said nothing, when you see her say "Well, you know, I really am the protector of women," is -- do you think it's a credible posture for her?

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: I -- I mean it's -- it's -- it's consistent for her. This is exactly what she has done throughout her entire career. I mean remember a few years ago she brought Emma Sulkowicz, the Mattress girl, the performance--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: --audience from Columbia to the State of the Union address. This was a woman who had, you know, as a performance dragged her mattress around Columbia University campus claiming that they wouldn't expel her rapist but he'd been found to be, you know, not culpable. I -- I think that this--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The rapist who wasn't a rapist.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: --the rapist who wasn't a rapist.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Right.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: This is, you know, Senator Gillibrand has -- has seized this issue and the MeToo movement and the question of abuse and harassment as her issue and this is how she's, you know--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: --moving forward.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Is there anything she won't do? I guess we'll find out soon as she runs with the creepy porn lawyer for the Democratic nomination.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: It'd be great.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Seth, please keep covering it. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BARRON
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: One female observer for the Brett Kavanaugh saga says that his accuser's story is missing critical details, the details that would be needed to have any hope of determining whether he's guilty or not. She joins us to explain next. Penny Young Nance, president and CEO of Concerned Women for America, says the timing of Dr. Ford's allegation is suspicious.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Penny Young Nance is President and CEO of Concerned Women for America. She just wrote a piece arguing that Christine Ford's account of an assault by Brett Kavanaugh is missing essential details, the rest of us need to assess it. Penny Young Nance joins us tonight. Penny, thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: PENNY YOUNG NANCE, CONCERNED WOMEN FOR AMERICA
utterances.sentences: It's great to be here, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, I think most people watching this came into it with a pretty open mind. I know feminists always saying no one believes the long-ago. Well most people I know want to believe--

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --but it's hard because there are missing details. What should we know that we don't in order to assess this?

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: Well, first let me tell you, I'm coming at this as a woman who has been a victim of an attempted rape and a physical assault when I was pregnant with my first child in a running path in Virginia. I have written a whole chapter in my book about that issue. I've testified before Congress advocating for women and victims of sexual violence, advocating for the Debbie Smith Act, and written numerous, you know, op-eds about this. This is an important issue to my heart. But I care about justice. And that's the missing piece here. We do believe that a person is innocent until proven guilty in this case. And it is we've got Judge Kavanaugh in an impossible position. People have noted this. You know, I would like to believe that women are always morally superior to men at the -- as the Head of Concerned Women for America.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: But the Duke Lacrosse case and Lena Dunham's book and, you know, even going back to classic literature to like To Kill a Mockingbird, we know that's not always true because we are broken people. The best that we can do is try to get to the truth and I appreciate--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well you're saying that that not every woman always tells the truth in every--

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: Yes, sadly--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --instance?

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: --that is the case. Of course, it is.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: And we know that you don't immediately become more moral because you -- because you're a woman. That's why justice must be blind.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: Justice has to be blind to everything, gender, race, socioeconomics, age, and we're counting on that. And if we get away from that notion, it is dangerous for our nation. It's dangerous for everyone in our country.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: If the presumption is that people are judged on the basis of their sex or race--

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: Right. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --or their immutable characteristics that's not--

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --a component, you say?

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: That's right. It absolutely is not. Now listen, I believe that -- I believe women. And I think we have a right to -- to use our voice and to speak up. And as a victim, we have to have the opportunity to come forward and share our perspective. But we also need to understand that we deserve to give justice to everyone in this nation. And Concerned Women for America is there for Judge Kavanaugh. We still support him. If something changes, if we actually is proven that he's a sexual predator or--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: --anyone sitting on the Supreme Court today, we would be the first people calling for impeachment.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm sure.

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: We would be leading the charge. But that's not where we are. And so, we strongly are still in support of him. In fact, we're doing a Women for Kavanaugh rally Thursday morning behind the Senate Russell Building 8:30 A.M to 9:30 A.M. Any of your viewers that want to come would be welcome. This is an important moment--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: --for conservative women to speak up on this issue.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Penny Nance, thank you very much for that.

utterances.speaker: NANCE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Megan Fox writes at PJ Media. She just wrote a piece telling parents how to Christine-Blasey-Ford-proof your son. She had four tips for all parents. Megan Fox joins us tonight. Megan, thanks a lot for coming on. So, what does this mean? How do you -- what's the prophylactic against getting accused of something? And what would you tell parents to tell their boys?

utterances.speaker: MEGAN FOX, PJ MEDIA CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Well there is no total prophylactic, of course. But I would tell them to first when they're young, you know, for sure, take them to church, give them a moral standing in life. Teach them about their -- their -- their dignity as a person, and the dignity of others. The second thing is to avoid drinking. Stay sober. Avoid girls who drink. Avoid these drunken parties that can be used against you in 30 years. And also, always act as if you are going to have a position of authority and a high position and act accordingly. It's like the Mike Pence School of Thought. Don't be alone with a woman who's not your wife.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wait a second. That's like crazy evangelical stuff. Isn't it?

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: That's what they've brought us to, Tucker. That's what they brought -- we're going to have to bring back chaperones. I mean there is no way to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Probably.

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: --I -- I -- I love my son, and I do not want my son to be accused falsely. And so he's going to have to cover--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: --himself.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're right. So, what's tip four?

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: Well, don't trust women. I think you just touched on that with your last--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: --with -- with your last guest. I mean the women are not paragons of virtue just by being a woman. You've ever heard of Delilah or Jezebel, you know, who fabricated evidence against Naboth because she wanted his vineyard. You know, women do lie. I want evidence. I believe evidence. I don't believe all women. I believe all evidence. And if Christine Blasey Ford--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What's so -- what's so funny is that spoken such like I mean I'm just being completely honest. I kind of do trust all women. I know I shouldn't, intellectually, but I think that most men, and the Left lies about this, instinctively trust women. I do think it's baked in our genetic cake. I do. That's how I feel anyway. And all the women I know are deeply suspicious of women's motives. Do -- do you notice this?

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: That's because we know what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Huh.

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: That's because I am a woman. I know this for a fact. I've known women my whole life. It is no--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: --women are just as easily evil as men. Women that are --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, I just don't believe that. But I -- I mean obviously--

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: --equally capable of evil.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I know you're right but it -- hard to convince me. Megan, thank you very much for that.

utterances.speaker: FOX
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well the Left is losing control as it is consumed with hysteria over Brett Kavanaugh. Now anyone, who knows Kavanaugh, thinks he's a decent person, is fair game for physical harassment. It is happening here in Washington. We'll show you how next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: An update tonight in our exclusive investigation into Google and how it manipulates the information you receive. The search giant's employees plan to rig search results for the sake of promoting political groups and undermining the Administration's immigration policies. We brought that to you exclusively last week. Now, shortly after our story, the CEO of Google, Sundar Pichai sent out a staff-wide email. He said in part, "We do not bias our products to favor any political agenda. The trust our users place in us is our greatest asset. If any Google user undermines that trust, we will hold them accountable." Google has already told us it won't punish any of the employees who planned to subvert Google's search. So, if they're lying to us about holding people accountable, and they are, why should we believe them when they claim they show no bias? Our investigation continues. Well the campaign to crush Brett Kavanaugh is consuming most of the energy of the Democratic Party right now. But it's going beyond just hearings and magazine pieces and cable news appearances. Now, according to some extremists, anyone who supports Kavanaugh is fair game for physical harassment. Just last night, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and his wife were targeted by a mob at a restaurant in Washington. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: SEN. TED CRUZ, R-TEXAS
utterances.sentences: It was a delight. Excuse me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Beto is way harder than you dude.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (CROSSTALK).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: CRUZ
utterances.sentences: God bless you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: God bless you too.

utterances.speaker: CRUZ
utterances.sentences: Excuse me, let my wife through.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (CROSSTALK).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well this is what it looks like to live under tyranny by rich kids with poetry degrees. These tactics are becoming increasingly common. Don't forget, just a few months ago, the DHS Secretary was targeted in exactly the same way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Shame. Shame.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Shame. Shame.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No borders. No walls. Sanctuary for all.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No borders. No walls. Sanctuary for all.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If kids don't eat in peace, you don't eat in peace.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If kids don't eat in peace, you don't eat in peace.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Abolish ICE. Abolish ICE. Abolish ICE. Abolish ICE.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Abolish ICE. Abolish ICE. Abolish ICE. Abolish ICE.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well you can see where this is going and it's not good. Instead of trying to slow it down or calm their voters, Democrats like Maxine Waters are cheering this kind of behavior on.

utterances.speaker: REP. MAXINE WATERS, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: If you see anybody from that Cabinet in a restaurant, in a department store, at a gasoline station, you get out and you create a crowd.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And you push back on them, and you tell them they are not welcome.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: David Burstein is progressive commentator and Democratic strategist. He joins us tonight. David, thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: DAVID BURSTEIN, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: Hi Tucker, good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Are your parents still on ?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. They -- yes, my parents are on. They're watching--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --tonight probably, hi mom and dad.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh great. What's -- what's -- what's their home address, so I can send some people over to scream at them?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I -- I'm not -- I'm not going to give out my parents' home address on television.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. And -- and by the way, and just to be totally clear, I would - - I would never encourage anyone to bother your parents or you outside of the conversation we're having because that's immoral, and it's wrong. It's outside the boundaries of political debate and it crosses over into harassment. So why are Democrats making excuses for their voters hassling and physically confronting people like Ted Cruz in restaurants?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Look, I -- I -- I obviously don't think it's a good idea to encourage people to go harass other people. I don't think Maxine Waters is correct and in -- in saying "Go harass people out." However, I do think that if you're a public official, you should be willing to stand on principle by your positions. Occasionally, that may get not so pretty for you. You may have people in public come out and say those things.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We believe survivors.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I wish we didn't have a political discourse --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, I don't -- I don't understand. So, what is -- what is, so but hold on--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --on that basis.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I mean one thing about Cruz, whatever you think of Cruz, not everyone loves Cruz. I get it. But Cruz is a guy who's happy to stand on his principles and to debate them and to explain them at great length. He loves to talk about what he believes. You can always talk to Ted Cruz about what he believes. They're not trying to talk to Ted Cruz or challenge his principles. They're trying to wreck his dinner--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I think -- I think -- I -- I -- I don't -- I think -- I think that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and scare his wife.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --I think that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --so what is this ? I don't get it.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: -- everyone would get more if they had gone up to Ted Cruz to, you know, lay out their case or lay out their points to him. So, I don't think it's a good idea to encourage people to harass you. And I actually don't think you accomplish much by doing that. But I think for public officials to be whining or complaining that they're being -- they're being harassed in public takes out of the notion of public service the public piece of it, which is that people--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. So then let's -- let's -- -- let's get back to showing up at your parents' house. So, I disagree with what you're saying. I think what you're saying is wrong. And I think it's frankly bad for the country. So, to express that, why would it be illegitimate for me to show up on your parents' doorstep--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Because Tucker, you know--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and scream obscenities at them?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --you and everyone know, my parents are not in public service. They've not chosen to live a public life.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What do -- what do you mean? They gave birth to you--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Oh, oh, oh, oh--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and so by, no, no, but I mean no, no, but hold on by your--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --come on.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --look, let me just be totally clear that this is like a swiftly argument, I hate this stuff. I think it's totally wrong. I -- and I think we should shut it down immediately. I would never bother you or your parents--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Yes but--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --but I just want you to think through the logic of what you said, which is if I don't agree with someone--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --I -- I -- no, they're -- they're -- they're Tucker, Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I get to scream them at dinner.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --Tucker, you know -- you know that you're -- what -- the point that you're making right now is dishonest. There's a big difference between--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: There is nothing dis -- whoa, whoa settle down --

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --private citizens and public--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --no, there is--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --and public servants -- public servants--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --who have run for election, who've put themselves out there--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --you have a lot of ways to serve this country. If Ted Cruz wanted to serve this country as a private citizen--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So if -- if you give --

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --there's a lot of ways to do that. And you know what, privately in that case you don't have anyone throwing up at dinner --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --there's no -- there's no meaningful -- there's no meaningful distinction--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: There's, of course, there's a meaningful distinction.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --so anybody, hold on, no there is not.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: There's a total difference between people who are public figures- -

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --because no, no, there is not -- what do you mean?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --and the law bears the facts. The law --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're a public -- you're a public figure, David.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --about how it figures --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're the one who's being dishonest and cowardly.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I'm not being cowardly.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're the one who operates a website--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Uh oh--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --who tries to get public support so you can make money.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Hey--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: All of us are in the business of winning others to our side. All of us are engaged in the public debate. If he's opening himself--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: No, no, Tucker, Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --up to getting screamed out with his wife, so are you and so am I.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --Tucker, that is -- that is -- that I -- I do not -- to be clear, I do not think we should encourage people to go harass people.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You think?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: But people in this people -- I -- I -- and I don't think that should even be up for debate--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's disgusting.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --because it's a ridiculous -- it's a ridiculous idea. But I'm saying that if people like Ted Cruz are going to -- are going to try and play a victim card and act like some terrible thing--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: He -- look, he is the vic--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --has been perpetrated he is -- he is--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --this he had people his wife at dinner--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --people -- he has people to be able to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --why is it so hard, no, wait, wait--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --toughen up a little bit and take some people at -- at an -- at a -- at a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh? Should his wife -- wait, slow -- slow down. Let me -- I ask the questions on this show, pal. So let me ask you this question--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --is his wife should have -- stop -- should his wife--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --per person menu restaurant have a little discomfort.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --tough enough. Really? Mr. Tough guy. I wish you were here because I'd --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --like to ask you this question. Is his wife--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: Well it see -- it see -- it -- it seems that--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --not tough enough?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --he's tough enough to allow his wife--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, no, what about his wife?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --to endure -- endure insults from Donald Trump before--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, no but hold on--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --before going and standing side by side with him--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, so he deserves it.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --and he needs his political support. So I think the idea--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, you're -- you're totally cool with Heidi being intimated?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That doesn't bother you because it serves your -- your purposes politically?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I don't -- I don't -- I do -- again--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're totally for it. You're making excuses for it--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I do not -- I do not encourage anyone to -- to engage in this kind of behavior--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, you know what? Those are weasel words.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: No, it's not -- it's not a -- it's not a weasel argument.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, you are. He should be tough enough--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: But this he's -- he's the--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --that it's his fault his wife got screamed at. This I'm going to save this tape--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: In -- in a culture -- in a culture--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --when you get to be an adult, you'd be embarrassed of this.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --that has been created by this President and this Administration--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: A culture has it's just OK. I'm trying not to use profanity on the internet so I'm going to stop--

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --of bullying and harassment you shouldn't be surprised, you shouldn't be surprised that things like this end up happening, frankly--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --right, yes all right, yes, all right.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --culture starts at the top.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's Trump's fault. OK. Where were you educated? Really quick, where'd you go to college just so I know not to send any of my kids there?

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: I went -- I was -- I'm a proud graduate of New York University, very--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Ah perfect, off the list.

utterances.speaker: BURSTEIN
utterances.sentences: --very proud to be one.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. Good to see you. Brett Kavanaugh saga feels like more than just another political fight. It seems to say something important about this country, but what? Victor Davis Hanson has an idea and he shares it with us next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry to do this. But I sometimes get texts from viewers on the show. We just did a segment on Ted Cruz's wife being confronted in a restaurant by angry young progressives. And I just got this text. How come these kids who confront Ted Cruz never confront Ryan Zinke , which is a good question. I think we know. Well the fight over Brett Kavanaugh feels like something brand-new in American politics in some ways. The willingness to destroy him personally and to overthrow every norm of fairness and due process to do that seems like a sign of sickness, honestly, in our society, maybe one that's been building for a while. Victor Davis Hanson has been following it as a Senior Fellow at Hoover out in California. He just wrote a piece entitled We Are Living Nineteen Eighty-Four, and he joins us tonight. Professor, what do you mean We Are Living Nineteen Eighty-Four?

utterances.speaker: VICTOR DAVIS HANSON, HOOVER INSTITUTION SENIOR FELLOW
utterances.sentences: Well I think what we're doing is systematically destroying 2,500 years of Western jurisprudence and three centuries of American law on the basis that well it's a Supreme Court, so it's special or it's not a criminal case, so these rules don't apply. And we forget that the Constitution is our secular Bible whether you're -- you're under examination little-league or a grammar school we get inspiration for every process in our country. Our daily lives are based on the -- the inherent right to meet your accusers, to cross-examine, not to bring into evidence hearsay, to have detailed evidence, to have statutes of limitations, so we're going to throw all that out because the means are necessary for this noble end of -- of stopping Brett Kavanaugh. And then, culturally think of it a minute, Tucker, so now, everything that we know about our literature and culture just is out the window. So, Euripides wrote a play about Hippolytus. Phaedra was always right because she must be believed when she made a false accusation -- accusation. Tom Robinson was guilty because somebody accused him of being rape in To Kill A Mockingbird. And whether that the Left likes it or not, they're making a Manichaean choice now. Millions of Americans are watching them and they're saying to themselves, whatever my views are on Donald Trump for, against, pro, or con, they're making this, they mean the Senate Democrats and this MeToo radical movement and the effort to destroy Kavanaugh, they're saying we're the issue and--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: HANSON
utterances.sentences: --a lot of people are saying "If you're going to make me, if you're going to make that choice, I don't want to vote against jurisprudence and the U.S. Constitution." And I don't know if they know it but they're forcing people to make a choice, you're either with us or against us. A lot of people are going to say "I'm with the Constitution, the tradition of American law--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Boy, I hope so.

utterances.speaker: HANSON
utterances.sentences: --and fairness."

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The good news is in a moment like this, the rare people that tell the truth stand out because they're brave and you're one of those people. And we appreciate it, professor. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HANSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well for once the new cycle is being dominated by someone who is not Donald Trump. But the President did address the U.N. today. We'll show you some of what he said. It was actually pretty interesting. Stay tuned. Julio Borges fled Venezuela to escape the horrors of Nicolas Maduro's socialist government.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The President spoke at the United Nations today in New York. During his speech, he condemned the socialist and corrupt government of Venezuela. Here's a part of what he said.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Not long ago Venezuela was one of the richest countries on earth. Today, socialism has bankrupted the oil-rich nation and driven its people into abject poverty.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. No toilet paper, eating zoo animals, not going well. We recently spoke to Venezuelan Opposition Leader Julio Borges, who fled the country to escape being killed by the government of Nicolas Maduro. Here's part of our conversation.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: When you hear young Democrats identify themselves as socialists, what's your response?

utterances.speaker: JULIO BORGES, VENEZUELAN POLITICIAN
utterances.sentences: Well I'm shocked, you know, because I -- I can talk by my experience in Venezuela is socialism in Venezuela has meant expropriating thousand of companies and losing millions of jobs in the name of the poor people. But at the end, it has meant to abolish freedom, to abolish progress, to violate human rights, all in the name of socialism. So, for me, there is no reason why some people can back up and support this kind of ideas right now when the worlds need free trades, democracy, progress, and human rights?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We -- we know that under socialism, the rich get poorer but the promise is what they tell us is that the poor get much richer, is that true?

utterances.speaker: BORGES
utterances.sentences: On the contrary. Venezuela was one of the most richest countries in the world. It was a -- a land where the people went in the 20th Century looking for -- for progress. And now, we are in a real misery. 5 million people has left Venezuela, and in the name of socialism, a -- economy has been destroyed and there is no freedom in order to do whatever you want to do. And we have the -- probably the highest hyperinflation in the history of the world. We can -- we could end this year with 1 millionth percent of hyperinflation. And this is a direct consequence of the system to control price, expropriation, state trying to control everything in the economic sector, and it has been a real failure producing more and more poverty in Venezuela.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: This has happened, as far as I know, in every place that comprehensive socialism has been tried. Why do you think people keep trying it or keep supporting it?

utterances.speaker: BORGES
utterances.sentences: Well sometimes you see, for example, socialism has been a failure not only Venezuela, also in Nicaragua--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BORGES
utterances.sentences: --or Cuba in Latin America, in Eastern Europe, in this former Soviet Union -- from -- former Union, so there is no one single example of a good success of socialism because socialism at the end always ended in totalitarianism , in a dictatorship. And in the case of Venezuela, we are beyond a dictatorship. Right now, we are like a failure at the state like a narco-state. And all over Venezuela there is no institutions but corruption at different groups trying to -- to get the money from the oil. And so, always that is the -- the end of any socialistic scheme to -- to any democracy in the world.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You may have noticed from all the news with this week, the many things liberals once argued in favor of, they now oppose, civil rights, due process, free speech. Why? Because they have the power now. They're the establishment. That's the subject of my new book. It's called Ship of Fools. It's out next week. Tomorrow, after the show, we'll be doing a live book signing. It'll take place on our Facebook page @tuckercarlsonFOX, also link to it on the Tucker Carlson Tonight Facebook page. We're taking questions from viewers, signing books. You'll be able to pre- order them if you want. Mark Steyn will be there too because everything is better with Mark Steyn. You can order a -- an autographed copy right now in shipoffools.com, and you can submit your questions. Tomorrow night, Facebook @tuckercarlsonFOX. That's it for us -- shipoffoolsbook.com, they're telling me. Anyway that's it for us tonight. We'll be back tomorrow and every night to fight pomposity, and smugness, and groupthink. Sean Hannity, right now. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
